Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Revert "[Cookie Compliance] The new cookie compliance pipeline. (#8209)"" (#8233) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened pull request "Revert "[Cookie Compliance] The new cookie compliance pipeline. (#8209)"" (#8233) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "Move Search backend to Azure Search" (#6371) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "Response status code does not indicate success: 400 (The <icon> element is not currently supported.)" (#8204) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
We use release https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09
When try to push package downloaded from nuget.org, get error:
`
Response status code does not indicate success: 400 (The <icon> element is not currently supported.).
`
### To Reproduce
`Pushing System.Runtime.CompilerServices.Unsafe.4.7.1.nupkg to 'https://localnuget/api/v2/package'...`
`PUT https://localnuget/api/v2/package/`
`BadRequest https://localnuget/api/v2/package/ 2021ms`
`Response status code does not indicate success: 400 (The <icon> element is not currently supported.).`

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PM UI changes - unify Update/Installed tab" (#8290) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently the update/installed tabs differ in 3 ways. 

1. On the installed tab, all top level dependency are displayed.  On the updates tab, only the ones that have newer versions on the selected source(s) are displayed. 
1. The updates tabs has checkboxes that are used to allow a multi package update. 
1. The updates label has a number that says how many packages have updates. 

My proposal is to merge these 2 tabs into since so much of the information is redundant. 

1. Add a new checkbox to filter packages with updates only. 
1. Keep the checkboxes on by default (or enable it when the updates only filter is checked). 
1. Keep the label on the newly consolidated tab. 

//cc @karann-msft @anangaur Thoughts?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[CPVM-Perf] Reduce the PackageSpec clone when adding the CPVM information " (#10003) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

During the processing step of PackageVersion a [clone](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/e97d556a83750bb4f8017e3640bc699d04832657/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.ProjectModel/DependencyGraphSpec.cs#L262) is performed. Reduce the cloning step.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VS Rebuild doesn't reinstall changed packages into global-packages (In last version 16.8.0 preview 3.1)" (#10060) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I have solution with 2 projects. 
First project produces nuget package into local repository. 
Second project consumes this package.
I had to rebuild the project for the modified package to be reinstalled into `global-packages`.

But today I've updated Visual Studio to version 16.8.0 preview 3.1. And now rebuild doesn't reinstall the modified package. I'm forced to clear `global-packages` manually.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Pack should validate the case of files referenced by the .nuspec because NuGet.org validation is case sensitive" (#10102) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

### Pack should validate the case of files referenced by the .nuspec because NuGet.org validation is case sensitive

#### Background
For approx 3 months we had been building a NuGet package daily, hosting on an internal NuGet repository and using within Visual Studio. On the day we planned to release our NuGet packages on NuGet.org, they failed validation due to a missing file, when the file was technically present but the fale name case did not match the nuspec. This caused us to scramble to rename the file, replace in multiple NuGet packages and re-sign each package in order to keep on track with our release schedule.

#### Details
- Actual file name/case inside the NuGet package: `\legal\eula.txt`
- File name/case in the Nuspec reference: `<license type="file">legal/EULA.txt</license>`
- Note NuGet pack did not report any issues in our internal build pipeline
- The package appeared to work OK in Visual Studio when using our internal NuGet server. Or so we thought...
- The package failed NuGet.org validation with the error `The license file 'legal/EULA.txt' does not exist in the package.`

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): NuGet.exe

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):

VS version (if appropriate):

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): 

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:

N/A

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Take an existing NuGet package
2. Replace a file within the package with a lowercase named version of the same file
3. Attempt to upload to NuGet.org

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...)

### Sample Project

Very helpful if you can zip a project and paste into this issue!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Improve the diagnosis tools for authentication problems " (#10101) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
In particular, VS can be a problem because the VS authentication experience is interactive. 

We frequently get claims of *too many* prompts by customers, but we have no means to correlate whether that's because of NuGet or the plugin misbehaving.

In general, when things *do go wrong*, it'd be helpful to have some info to better understand what happened.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Move Image assets to Image Service & delete unnecessary assets" (#10000) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Evaluate all resource files here: NuGet.PackageManagement.UI\Resources\

Refactoring is needed to move from resource files to
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/extensibility/image-service-and-catalog?view=vs-2019

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The down icon icon when the latest package version is installed is not intuitive. The old green tick was perfect" (#9789) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The NuGet package manager in Visual Studio shows a green "arrow down" icon when the **latest version** of the package is **already installed**:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/743918/87300628-d6af8180-c516-11ea-8b0c-c671499c08d1.png)

The current "arrow down" icon is more commonly associated with the "_A new version is available to download_" idea than with "_The version is up to date_".

It used to show a green tick, which was more intuitive:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/743918/87300801-360d9180-c517-11ea-8c99-46afea507b3f.png)
(Image taken from https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/install-use-packages-visual-studio)

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: VS UI
VS version (if appropriate): 2019

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No idea of the version when it was changed

## Other suggested things (optional)

Since we're at it, I'd like to suggest using these icons:

**Latest version** installed: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/743918/87301155-baf8ab00-c517-11ea-898d-f51a8e7dda89.png)
Like I said above, it's basically the previous icon which was shown by VS 

**New version** available:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/743918/87301387-2b9fc780-c518-11ea-9bb8-eb6992a1d4a7.png)
 (maybe with dark yellow instead of blue)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet crashes in VS" (#10037) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: VS UI

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 5.7

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): N/A

VS version (if appropriate): 16.7.3

OS version: Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19041.508]

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: N/A

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Add chocolatey NuGet feed `https://chocolatey.org/api/v2/` in Options > NuGet Package Manager > Package Sources
2. Open 'Manage NuGet Packages in any project/solution
3. Select chocolatey NuGet feed
4. Search for 'legendary'
